title: Can we use I in an essay? - Quora

response.answer_text: I consistent scored high 90s on my college research papers and essays. (I know, shocking right, Im rusty considering I have not been writing anything at all for the last 6 months.) My advice is to avoid using the, and that. These words are literary glue. They do not add meaning and using too much of them will make your writing seem ungainly and fragmentary. You should try to write from an aloof, omniscient point of view so avoid using I, my or me. As an exercise, try constructing a paragraph or journal entry without using a single ‘the’. Instead, opt to use connective words like however, although, furthermore and while instead of THE. You will notice how much better your writing flows. What ever you do dont write ‘in my opinion’. Always aim to show, rather than tell.

I really don’t know what the exact requirements are nowadays but I remember being told when I was at college that for certain essays a carefully considered personal opinion is required. This must be based on evidence from various sources that you quote and evaluate. In the final analysis it must surely then be necessary to use ‘I’ as in for example “Based in the evidence given, my personal opinion is that….. and….. because….. and I believe that….. etc.”

No. And using "one" to mean "I" is frowned upon, too. The original question said "a formal essay". If the prof will accept something that falls into the hazy continuum between essay and short story, then using "I" is okay.
